results.title: TV news: behind the scenes
results.creator_credit: Michael Livesey, Randolph Hobler, John Barnes and Encyclopaedia Britannica Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World of work”.
Follows one day’s preparation of an evening TV news broadcast at a major New York studio, showing how stories are assigned and reported, with examples of on the spot coverage. Concentrates on the editorial and technical teamwork involved in the selection and final preparation of news stories to be presented on air, with special emphasis on the contributions of key members of the newsroom staff. Narrated by John Barnes.

results.title: Microchips rule OK
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “The World of work”.
A short and impressionistic film which poses the question are computers a good or bad thing for the workforce? Includes interviews with unemployed youth, workers and archival footage of the introduction of computers into the workplace. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: The World of work
results.brief_description: A series of short films which look at different aspects of work in Australia. Of particular interest to adolescents. Teacher’s notes accompany the videos.

results.title: The Three Stooges. Vols 24-26
results.brief_description: Compilation of three videos starring the Three Stooges in some of their funniest films. Titles include “Nutty but nice” (dir. Jules White); Gripes, grunts & groans” (dir. Jack White); “Three little pirates (dir. Edward Bernds); “Horsing around” (dir. Jules White); “Hoofs and goofs” (dir. Jules White); “Flying saucer Daffey” (dir. Jules White); “Guns a poppin” (dir. Jules White); “Sweet and hot” (dir. Jules White); “Bubble & trouble” (1953). The Three Stooges consisted of Moe Howard, Shemp Howard and Larry Fine.

results.title: TV sale
results.creator_credit: Ernie Schmidt, Don Worobey, John Taylor, Peter Jones and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The opening pitch of the television salesman pretty well establishes the tone of this pithy animation film: a solid-state model guarantees high-quality entertainment. TV Sale is an entertaining, incisive and horrifying satire on some of the material that is disgorged via the “boob tube.” Programs are designed around the product, not the spectator.

results.title: View from the typewriter
results.creator_credit: Robert Duncan, George Johnson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A compilation of excerpts from National Film Board of Canada documentaries that deal with Canadian writers and their sense of place. Featuring readings from the works of Hugh MacLennan, W.O. Mitchell, Jack Hodges, Farley Mowat, Margaret Laurence, Earle Birney, Malcolm Lowry, Leonard Cohen, Margaret Atwood and Milton Acorn, the documentary examines how Canadian writers have attempted to make sense of a landscape and a geography that traverses huge differences of scale, topography and climate. The readings are powerful, including Richard Burton reading from Lowry’s work, and though specific to the Canadian experience, the film is also relevant to Australian writing about extremes of location. Just like English speaking Canadians, our writing too grapples with making sense of a country and terrain which encompasses the duality of being both “new” and ancient.

results.title:
Chronophotographic prints
Movements in Pole Vaulting
results.credit_line: Courtesy Art Collection 4 / Granger Historical Picture Archive / Alamy
results.brief_description: French scientist Étienne-Jules Marey’s chronophotographic technique captured kinetic motion through multiple exposures in one photo. He used a photographic rifle with a revolving cylinder that shot 12 frames a second.
results.credit_line_for_label: Courtesy Art Collection 4 / Granger Historical Picture Archive / Alamy
